user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtAssert_EndTest:
```c
void UtAssert_EndTest(void)
{
    uint32                 Ct;
    bool                   SegmentValid;
    UtAssert_TestCounter_t Local_SegmentCounters;
    char                   Local_SegmentName[sizeof(CurrentSegment)];

    UT_BSP_Lock();

    SegmentValid = (UT_SegmentCounters.TotalTestCases > 0);
    if (SegmentValid)
    {
        ++UT_TotalCounters.TestSegmentCount;
        UT_SegmentCounters.TestSegmentCount = UT_TotalCounters.TestSegmentCount;
        UT_TotalCounters.TotalTestCases += UT_SegmentCounters.TotalTestCases;
        for (Ct = 0; Ct < UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MAX; ++Ct)
        {
            UT_TotalCounters.CaseCount[Ct] += UT_SegmentCounters.CaseCount[Ct];
        }
        memcpy(&Local_SegmentCounters, &UT_SegmentCounters, sizeof(Local_SegmentCounters));

        /*
         * note, strcpy is OK because both are fixed size buffers of the same size,
         * and the null termination on CurrentSegment was locally enforced already
         */
        strcpy(Local_SegmentName, CurrentSegment);
    }

    memset(&UT_SegmentCounters, 0, sizeof(UT_SegmentCounters));

    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    if (SegmentValid)
    {
        UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport(Local_SegmentName, &Local_SegmentCounters);
    }
    else
    {
        UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_END, "No test cases\n");
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtAssert_EndTest:
UtAssert_TestCounter_t UT_TotalCounters   = {0}
...
UtAssert_TestCounter_t UT_SegmentCounters = {0}
...
typedef struct
{
    uint32 TestSegmentCount;
    uint32 TotalTestCases;
    uint32 CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MAX];
} UtAssert_TestCounter_t
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No suspicious for-loop fragments found. The only for statement is: for (Ct = 0; Ct < UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MAX; ++Ct) { UT_TotalCounters.CaseCount[Ct] += UT_SegmentCounters.CaseCount[Ct]; }
- Clause 1: the first clause sets only the loop counter (Ct = 0).
- Clause 2: the condition uses only the loop counter and a compile-time constant (UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MAX); it has no persistent side-effects and does not reference any object modified in the loop body.
- Clause 3: the iteration expression increments only the loop counter (++Ct) and does not modify other objects.
- Clause 4: there is a single loop counter (Ct) and it is not modified in the loop body; the body performs only indexed updates to CaseCount arrays and contains no function calls that could have side effects on the loop control.
No other for loops are present in the function. Therefore, under MISRA C:2023 Rule 14.2 this code fragment does not require further investigation.
